Momentum and its conservation;collisions — Part 1.

We define momentum. Also revise Newton's Laws and impulse in the concepts pages for Newton's Laws and for Impulse. Collisions are a good illustration. Part 2 gives more powerful techniques for collisions, for instance in particle physics.

Definition of momentum For a particle, momentum is mass times velocity: $\valuedef{\vtr {p}}{m \vtr {v}}{}$ .
It is a vector vector with units $\quantity{}{kg\, m\, s\sup {-1}}$ .
Quick Questions

Two particles are moving in the same direction with momentum 
$\quantity{10}{kg\,  m\,  s\sup {-1}}$
. What is their total momentum?

Two particles are moving in opposite directions, each with momentum 
$\quantity{10}{kg\,  m\,  s\sup {-1}}$
. What is their total momentum?

Conservation of momentum The momentum is conserved in the absence of forces external to the system. 
This concept is one of the most important in physics and follows from Newton's laws. Newton's second law (N2L, "force = mass times acceleration") can be written:

$\displaystyle \vtr {F} = m \vtr {a} = m \d\vtr {v}/\d t = \d\vtr {p}/\d t . $
N1L says that in the absence of forces, particles continue moving without further change of velocity. Setting $\valuedef{\vtr {F}}{0}{}$ in N2L above shows that then $\vari{\vtr {v}}$ is unchanging, as is momentum $\vari{\vtr {p}}$ , that is momentum is conserved. Consider a system consisting of two particles colliding head on, figure 1 (a). The box indicates the system is "closed" — there are forces within it (when the particles collide), but not on it from outside.
(a) The collision of two particles isolated from the rest of the world. (b.1) Two particles before an inelastic collision (b.2) sticking together after inelastically colliding.

$\displaystyle \vtr {p}_1 + \vtr {p}_2 = \vtr {p}_1' + \vtr {p}_2' $
where the prime $'$ ' indicates after the collision.

Impulse Impulse is the change of momentum. It is force times time, for a constant force acting. The term is generally (but not always) used when momentum is transferred over a short time (e.g. during a collision). It is described fully in the impulse concept sheet.
